title: What will U.S. holiday season retail sales be for 2020 relative to the 2019 holiday season?
possible_answers: Higher by more than 0.0% but less than 2.5%
preds: With all these questions closing in a few hours The Great Reversion to the Mean Event is at hand. (I don't know about you, but I've got many questions that have had a crowd score of 0 or 100 for months which will resolve tomorrow.)  Happy New Years! Everyone

-15 on over 5%. I see links in the comments about a number around 3% for this season, but that looks like it's based on a MasterCard spending pulse analysis, and looking at the previous years I don't see much correlation between the MasterCard spending pulse year over year holiday growth and the Census data holiday growth. That said, in case I'm looking at the data incorrectly or missing something I'm coming down a bit on over 5%, though I still think it's more likely. There would have to be a pretty big decline from November 2020 to December 2020 to drop it under 5%, and an impossibly large decline to go below 2.5%. Table of census data: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing 2019 MC spending pulse was 3.4%, census was 4.2%: https://chainstoreage.com/mastercard-spending-pulse-holiday-sales-34-fueled-big-online-increase
2018 MC spending pulse was 5.1%, census was 2.8%: https://newsroom.mastercard.com/press-releases/mastercard-spendingpulse-u-s-retail-sales-grew-5-1-percent-this-holiday-season/
2017 MC spending pulse was 4.9%, census was 6.2%: https://newsroom.mastercard.com/press-releases/mastercard-spendingpulse-retail-sales-grew-4-9-percent-this-holiday-season/

Here we go; For a 75 day period Bloomberg is reporting 3% (1), while Mastercard SpendingPulse is reporting 2.4% (1). 
While Reuters is reporting Mastercard Inc. stated a 3% growth in sales from Oct 11 - Dec 24 (75 Days) (2).
From Nov 1 - Dec 24, marketwatch is reporting 2.4% (3). Given this is only an indicator of the data we are sourcing the result from, and looking at the actual Nov results, I think we've undercooked buckets 4 and 5. 1. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-26/u-s-holiday-retail-sales-rose-3-driven-by-online-shoppers
2. https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-holidayshopping-idUSL4N2J33BB
3. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/us-holiday-sales-rose-24-as-online-sales-jump-2020-12-28

Forbes, Bloomberg, and Fortune all estimate holiday sales rose by 3%.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-26/u-s-holiday-retail-sales-rose-3-driven-by-online-shoppers

[2.5, 5.0] +10%
(5.0, inf) -10%
Reducing my risk relative to the crowd

The holiday retail sales thus far are 3% higher than last year.  Since there are only a few days left in the 2020 holiday retail season, these numbers are pretty close to the final figures. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-26/u-s-holiday-retail-sales-rose-3-driven-by-online-shoppers

Rolling back. 
Overreacted to monthly data on this one. The original premise of sales being spread out over a longer timeframe this time around might see growth taper off towards the end seems to be coming true.

https://www.wsj.com/articles/holiday-shoppers-steered-clear-of-stores-favoring-online-buying-11608984001?mod=hp_lead_pos2  Not the Census Bureau, but it's some hint of what's going on.  It's so close to 2.5% that I'm sticking with 60/40 for now. If you can't access the link, it says "U.S. retail sales rose 2.4% between Nov. 1 and Christmas Eve compared with the same period last year, according to Mastercard SpendingPulse, which tracks online and in-store spending with all forms of payment. Online sales grew 47.2% during that time, said the firm. The tally excludes sales of gas and autos."
Bad reading of info on my part combined with complete misunderstanding of American consumer. I suspect elsewhere will be lower and let that cloud my forecasting.

For the sales to be higher than 2.5%. The December sales have to be lower by 6% on a month on month basis. ie Sales in Dec20 compared to Nov20. (While Nov did decline 1.1% and Consumer confidence has dipped suggesting a further decline this month as well, probability of it being as high as 6% seems very unlikely)
On my way to Walmart right now!

Based on the November release, this question can still resolve with >5% if month over month sales in Dec fall by less than 1.3%. For the question to resolve in the 2.5-5% bucket, sales must fall between 1.3-6%. Neither is not unreasonable (they fell by 2.4% from Feb to Mar this year and 14% from Mar to Apr). On the other hand, sales fell by only 0.8% in Nov and <0.1% in Oct.  While lockdowns are a drag, I think it’s a mistake to equate current lockdowns with early-2020 ones given that there is much less uncertainty now.

I’m keeping a slightly pessimistic view. Travel related spending will be way off. Latest series consoles in short supply. Delivery capacity issues. Suspect more spending was done earlier than normal. I don’t understand the travel/visiting restrictions in USA (family in California “locked down”; other states not so much) but suspect that may also contribute?

The retail sales numbers were published for both October and November 2020.  Overall, sales are up 4.1% thus far this holiday season from last year.  Spending online is up around 29.2% from last year.  The current estimates show a range of 2% to 9% increase in sales compared to the 2019 holiday season. https://www.wsj.com/articles/us-economy-november-retail-sales-coronavirus-recovery-11608059514
hard to believe, but November results are 5.9% higher than Nov 2019!

Two factors could make me overweight bins 2 & 3 after November figures: /The uncertainty about Congress about a second financial COVID-19 relief program, which is even not fixed by  the time of writing, will have depressed the average American's expectation about December's disposable income, and will have delayed at least some consumption decisions in November and December.
And if the relief package finally becomes law, maybe on 26 December 2020, it is almost too late to really influence holiday season sales. Even if amazon and other companies offered a "shop-now-and-pay-in January"-referred payment program, this will not fully compensate for the delays in the lawmaking process.
/As mentioned before, the retailers did preparations for a "non-traditional" holiday retail sales-season. They actively encouraged shoppers to push ahead with their purchases already in October to stretch the season and avoid dangerous scenarios with respect to malls, small shops, and overcrowded inner cities and shopping miles.
The November 2020 figures may thus be artificially blown up, since the peak season will have shifted from, I'd guess, 10 December into late November. The total holiday spending in December would then fall short of usual expectations, since people (those who are reasonably smart) could stop shopping around today and self-quarantine, in order to be able to have their usual family gatherings around Christmas safely. However, a general notion of optimism and the good stock market returns of 2020 so far probably increase the total disposable income of a lucky few, which could have a major contribution to still-increasing (yoy), higher than expected December figures.
I not sure which effect will outweigh others, all the more there are only 16 days left until this question closes. I prefer "slightly better", which is the middle bin, for the time being.
Based on december census report. Somewhere around 5% more likely above than below.

Latest release just dropped, November 2020 is up 5.93% over November 2019. Looking at the November to December change December usually is very close to November. The biggest change since 2005 was in 2018 when December was down 2.56% from November. So looking at some rough numbers, if December is around where November is at it would be more than a 5% increase from December 2019. If it dropped like it did in 2018 December would still be a 3% gain over December 2019. Based on that I'm -10 on the 0 to 2.5% category and +55 on higher by more than 5%. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing

Depleting down 0 to 2.5 and adding into up 2.5 to 5 and up over 5 categories. Just based on increased confidence that a drop is unlikely. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit#gid=0

Despite many wishing that spending makes for a happier holiday season, and admitting my personal bias is entirely opposite, the facts I see are:
 - 'poor' results for Thanksgiving [1]
 - poor GDP forecast for 2020 [2]
 - unemployment higher than last year [3]
 - conservative trends in the markets [4]
 - restrictions on travel, large family gatherings, shopping in stores [5]
 - trend in the crowd forecast for this question [1]  https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamdanziger/2020/12/06/thanksgiving-weekend-retail-down-14-chances-of-hitting-nrfs-optimistic-holiday-forecast-fades/?sh=48d75c4654cb
[2]  https://www.imf.org/external/datamapper/NGDP_RPCH@WEO/BRA?year=2020
[3]  https://data.oecd.org/unemp/unemployment-rate.htm#indicator-chart
[4]  https://capital.com/gold-price-forecast-2021-and-beyond
[5]  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage

https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamdanziger/2020/12/06/thanksgiving-weekend-retail-down-14-chances-of-hitting-nrfs-optimistic-holiday-forecast-fades/?sh=48d75c4654cb "Thanksgiving Weekend Retail Down 14%. Chances Of Hitting NRF’s Optimistic Holiday Forecast Fades. "Right before Thanksgiving, the National Retail Federation . . .  predicted November-December holiday sales would increase between 3.6% and 5.2% over 2019, excluding automobile dealers, gasoline stations and restaurants.
. . . 
Then right afterward, it crushed that hope. Consumers spent 14% less compared to last year over the five-day Thanksgiving weekend through Cyber-Monday. . .  Rather, this year’s spending squared with that in 2018, according to the survey conducted by NRF and Prosper Insights and Analytics among 6,500+ American

Prior to Thanksgiving, the National Retail Federation projected sales to increase by 3.6% to 5.2% during the 2020 holiday season.  DeLoitte projected that holiday sales will increase 1% to 1.5% in 2020.  However, Black Friday sales were down 13% with the average American spending $312 in 2020 versus $362 in 2019.  Many experts attribute this difference to sales extending through all of November and December and because more consumers are shopping online.   Cyber Monday sales increased by 15.1% over 2019, which was the largest e-commerce day ever grossing almost $11B.  54% of Americans surveyed stated that they plan to spend the same amount in 2020 on holiday gifts as in 2019, and 8% plan on spending more.

https://thesouthern.com/business/local/joe-szynkowski-market-yourself-like-a-product/article_94b3e4a3-ca50-5c18-90aa-b636f824b324.html ". . . holiday retail sales are likely to increase 1.5%, according to Deloitte’s annual holiday retail forecast"
Getting ahead of the 12/16 announcement. If the November retail sales number is >$401,000 then we are on track for 5.0+%.

Retail "holiday season" is November and December.  Amazon Prime Day(s) in mid-October broke all the records for that event, which has become one of the major stuff-worship sacraments in the US.   This may presage robust sales in the ensuing months, or it may have so depleted consumers' bank accounts and shopping lists that traditional holiday sales will be relatively anaemic.  Sort of splitting the difference here, pending some more data.
Stay-at-home order for Los Angeles county for most of December, other populated and financially strong counties or even states as a whole may soon follow.
The people who have extra cash, will spend a bit more to make ourselves happier.  Other will try the same as last year, it won’t be possible.

apparently the public has fully embraced E Retail, but i suspect demands on transportation and delivery service will mimic Sears and Roebuck delivery windows of the 70'd (thats  2-8 weeks for youngsters).

The National Retail Federation expects 2020 holiday sales to rise between 3.6% and 5.2% year over year, amounting to between $755.3 billion and $766.7 billion. [1]
For this question, sales between $755.3 billion and $766.7 billion means up by 0 to 2.5%
[1]https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/23/retail-trade-group-forecasts-holiday-sales-rising-3point6percent-to-5point2percent.html

Since this includes on line sales, as of Nov 30 its already higher by about 3% same time last year. As long as stock market remains high overall sales will too. A lot of disposable income at the higher income brackets and signifiants higher saving for those employed. And unemployment is mostly at the bottom of the income brackets.  Leaves a lot of people with a higher amount of disposable compared to last year.
Slight shift upwards on the back of positive black friday sales figures.

Experts expecting a healthy rise:
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/23/retail-trade-group-forecasts-holiday-sales-rising-3point6percent-to-5point2percent.html
Early reports seem to bear that out: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/27/black-friday-2020-live-updates.html
sheer amount of cash in people's hand and ample time at hand.

October was up 6.85% from the previous year. Things may be weakening since no stimulus was passed and the virus has increased, but I still think it's likely that shopping is substituting for other spending that can't happen during the virus and I think this holiday season will be pretty strong. Spreadsheet of the data: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing
If someone has shown real courage in the face of covid, American shoppers are only next to American doctors & nurses

Many people are struggling financially but dealing with fear by buying items to feel better. As a very materialistic country I imagine a lot of people will be trying to comfort their children with gifts. As well as the feeling that nothing is guaranteed.

Local and regional mandates and restrictions may first and foremost hit the "Food Services" sector which is included in 44W72 and which represents restaurants, bars and other venues for dining and drinking, from November on, and which would otherwise stabilize the upcoming figures, see April 2020 figures. Other than the NRF statistics, which explicitly excludes food services as a significant share of turnover, this question includes Food Services and thus make a drop by 2.5% or more somewhat probable.
I'm beginning to lean into the idea that Trump may keep his promise to not provide stimulus to a country that wouldn't vote for him.
If travel is restrained - Consumers will make up for it on gifts and decortations
Covid will force restricted gatherings, parties, etc. and people will have less money to spend or borrow.

I base this on a number of factors:
1. The election is over and the nation will begin relaxing and spending
2. Stimulus Package approval
3. High income individuals (who are more likely to have work-from-home jobs) will have a large pool of surplus cash and will revenge-buy since they are unlikely to travel. These buyers will off set the poorer Americans who will cut back this year.

Since 1999 the average holiday season change (Nov/Dec) is an increase of around 3.56%.  This year's % change in retail sales compared to 2019:
Jan 3.9%
Feb 4.4%
Mar 1.0%
Apr -14.0%
May -3.9%
Jun 3.0%
Jul 3.8%
Aug 4.1%
Sep 5.9% Since 1999 the average year on year increase for Sep/Oct is 3.9%. These months numbers correlate with the holiday season retail sales, which typically change by around 1/3%.  If you double the 2020 September sales of 398,544 (+/-5%), you get 757,234 / 836,942 for Nov/Dec giving a change of 0.43% / 11% compared to 2019.. COVID cases are rising sharply.
The first stimulus package would have had an impact on the numbers, by now its impact has definitely diminished.
A second stimulus package is very possible, the size depends on the winner of the election (looking like Biden which may delay it, especially with a republican senate).
The most relatable year historically is 2008, which lead to a 3.4% decline. But, unemployment was higher then than it is now.
An escalation of domestic tension and uncertainty could lead to an increase in 'panic buying'.
I think given that the corona virus has completely massacred the economy spending is going to be minimal this holiday season. Way too many people out of work and too much uncertainty.

+10% to less than 2.5%
-10% to more than 5.0% https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/retail-sales-ex-autos

Historically, holiday spending trends are similar to non-holiday spending, and this was true for the 2008 recession (which saw a ~10% drop y/y). Spending trends this year have been flat after the lockdown months, so the most likely spending outcomes are +/- within 2.5%. I don't see a reason to believe a small uptick is more likely than a small downtick, so those get equal chances. There is a small chance of a higher increase, either by random chance or a sudden vaccine release leading to dramatically more economic activicy. I give this a combined probability of 10%. It is also reasonably possible that Covid will increase dramatically and lead to another downturn similar to the spring. This is unlikely to happen in the states with the most economic activity based on current trends but uncertainty is high so I give this a probability of 20%.

Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive and richest person in the world, said in a press release, “We’re seeing more customers than ever shopping early for their holiday gifts, which is just one of the signs that this is going to be an unprecedented holiday season.”
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-amazon-com-results/amazon-forecasts-jump-in-holiday-sales-and-pandemic-costs-idUSKBN27E3DV?il=0 Okay, but when does "retailers' all-important holiday season" start if lots of people are shopping early, either on on line at Amazon And Friends or in line at whatever physical shops are left?  If there is quite a lot of early shopping, total holiday shopping could look misleadingly dismal.    This could go a lot of ways.  People could start spending like drunken Senators now either in the expectation of either a new stimulus payment or to get the shopping done before their savings evaporate. Or they could put off spending pending a stimulus or in order to conserve savings.  Or they could do all their shopping early so as to beat the crowds in either the virtual or the physical shops.  Or they could do their big-ticket shopping early and the small stuff later.  Or the other way around.  In any of these cases, when do retail sales start counting as "holiday"?  If they don't try to characterize individual purchases as "holiday" but just calculate excess sales against some metric, how to distinguish holiday shopping from pandemical hoarding?  I hate this question, as you may have surmised, and so am fudging my numbers shamelessly (and probably incorrectly).

When the election is over there is going to be more clampdowns. that's going to hurt the economy. Not complicated and quite possibly not right.
Not clear, largely based on 2008/2009 percentage drop if negatively impacted, with a little optimism thrown in.

. . .

Retail sales are already well above their pre-pandemic levels and have been climbing for five straight months, which could signal strong spending growth for the holidays. At the same time, more than 12 million Americans remain unemployed and lawmakers continue to bicker over further fiscal support."

Normal would be between 2,5% and 5,0%. Both republicans and democrats will support the economy through covid, its unlikely retail sales will drop below 0% as stimulating the economy has become 'free', both from a political point of view, and in terms of interest payment on the debt that the government needs to raise to finance the stimuli.

Retail sales have shown a strong recovery. Online shopping I think serves as a good substitution for in person events people are hesitant to participate in, like concerts, eating out, and other things. The big factor is the fact that no new coronavirus relief has been passed. I assume the CARES act played a role in the strong retail recovery, and that could wane by the holidays. On the other hand, people may have been saving some of that money or they could substitute retail spending for other activities during the holidays. The drop in 2008 was 4.3%, I don't think we'll see a drop anywhere close that and I think an increase is more likely based on recent months. It'll be interesting to see how October falls out, I'll revise my forecast once we have that data. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing
People will spend for the holidays to make themselves feel better after a difficult year - even those who are struggling financially.
No idea. starting point to study this question.

There has only been 1 year since 2002 that has seen a year over year decrease in holiday spending and that was 2008. Obviously, the economic situation is closer to the situation in 2008 than it was in 2019, which saw a strong economy. However, consumer spending since April has soared past even pre-pandemic levels, which indicates consumers are willing to spend and have the resources to do so. It will not be an earth-shattering increase but i would expect about a 2 percent bump, still below average, in spending for the holidays.

Retail sales fell -4.7% between 2007-2008. The only period they have falled in 20 years. The following year was flat. But beyond those years sales have grown a consistent 3-4%. Deloitte expects growth to stall rather than fall, at between 1% - 1.5%. There is some uncertainty that comes from an unknown election outcome - less the result, and more the consequences of that result. An unseemly transfer of power, or protracted dispute, could cause uncertainty that would depress consumer sentiment.

Factors for higher spending: Covid fatigue, stress, loneliness, etc. have people looking  for something that makes them feel good. Shopping! Also, can’t visit relatives, but can send them stuff. Retail shopping is a release valve waiting to blow open. 
Factors for lower: economy still poor for working class, with bars, restaurants, stores etc still curtailed.  And little Govt stimulus.  So less $ to spend. In any event, whether up or done a large percentage will be online.

Less vacation travel, less eating out, less experience based gift options are likely through the remainder of the calendar year, especially with the second wave fast approaching. 
A possible pandemic relief package could add to a YOY spending increase.  If we average 4.0% YOY growth prior to 2020, we seem poised to get close or exceed this trend baseline.

The question says that "outcome will be determined using seasonally adjusted "Retail Trade and Food Services, ex Auto and Gas" data from the U.S. Census Bureau for November and December 2020".
The holiday season is starting early this time around will have a downward impact
The resurgence in covid cases would also have a negative impact. On the other hand this still indicates a positive consumer sentiment as we head into the holiday season
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-sentiment-idUSKBN27129P

Retail sales generally increase at an average of 4.2 percent per month year over year according to FRED (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/RSXFS#0). Retail sales data shows show a rebound in 2020 with a positive percent change year-over-year since June. This trend looks likely to continue until the end of the year.  Projection is hedged at a growth rate between 2.5 and 5.0 percent due to continued economic headwinds due to a lack of fiscal stimulus policy. In the upcoming weeks, I will further investigate for a deterioration in median household spending, which would presumably provide guidance on spending during the holiday season.

Prime day for Amazon rose 60% for third party sales in 2020. While in-store purchases have been affected by the Pandemic, online stores are seeing all-time highs. New research Holiday Shopping trends suggest most small stores and all large retail companies have invested in their online presence and are making shopping easier than ever. Excluding the recession in 2008, holiday sales have increased every year by 2% or more since 2000 with only a 4% drop in 2008.
PS5 and Xbox sales will boost otherwise anemic numbers.

Same methodology but correcting spreadsheet error. Median is 4.4%, first quartile is 3.4%, first decile is 2.8%.  The only examples of negative YOY growth are 2008 & 2009. Is this recovery similar? Note to self: My intention was to enter this market at or near consensus as it is a subject I am familiar with but not knowledgable about. My research puts me very far from consensus. Right strategy or wrong strategy for this type of question? Additional note to self: I may be allowing @Anneinak's forecast to anchor my prediction shifting my odds to lower bins from where pure historical analysis would put it. Again, good idea or bad idea?

In a normal year, holiday sales are up 4.0% YOY. My hypothesis is that holiday sales will be closer to the 1st decile (1.5%) or 1st quartile (2.7%) this year. Counterargument is that July, August, September experienced 3.8%, 4.1% and 5.9% YOY growth respectively perhaps indicating pent up demand from March, April, May. How would a new round of covid relief impact this number? Or an upswing in coronavirus cases resulting in stricter capacity limitations or outright closing of bars, restaurants, and retail stores?

"Retail sales in the US jumped 1.9% month-over-month in September of 2020, following a 0.6% gain in August. 
Sales at clothing stores (11%); department stores (9.7%); sporting goods (5.7%); and auto dealers (4% ) recording the highest increases.  Sales also went up at food services and drinking places (2.1% ); health and personal care stores (1.7%); gasoline stations (1.5%); miscellaneous store retailers (1.1%); building material and garden equipment (0.6%); nonstore retailers (0.5%); and furniture stores (0.5%). 
In contrast, sales fell at electronics and appliance stores (-1.6%).  Retail sales excluding food services, car dealers, building-materials stores and gasoline stations, the so-called control group sales seen as a more reliable gauge of demand, increased 1.4%. Year-on-year, retail sales went up 5.4%, the strongest annual gain so far in 2020." (Source Trading Economics) Turmoil, protests, unrest related to presidential election results would affect retail sales. The likelihood of the US officials not declaring a winner weeks after the election due to the number of absentee and mail in ballots is significant.

I think travel and gift-giving are somewhat linked.
I've already heard one person say, "Since I'm not going to ___for Christmas, I'm not buying them any gifts."
